G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of child custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as applicable, and the prior orders of this Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of child custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as applicable, and the prior orders of this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing custody or parenting time order upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting time.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting time.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that the best interests of the child standard governs custody determinations, but it does not say that this standard governs all determinations of parenting time (visitation) in every context. The court discusses the best interests standard primarily in relation to custody under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and its interaction with statutory factors; it does not purport to state a universal rule for all parenting time determinations. Thus the proposition is overstated relative to what the case holds.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), first par. … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history…. [T]he ‘best interests’ standard … has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting time.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does apply a best-interests analysis, but not in the broad way the proposition claims. Yannas deals specifically with (1) an initial physical custody determination and (2) removal of children from the Commonwealth, and explains that “upon cause shown” in the removal statute means removal must be in the child’s best interests. It does not hold that the best‑interests standard governs all determinations of custody and parenting time in every context, so it is too narrow to support that sweeping proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262–63 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances can include changes in the child’s environment, the conduct or circumstances of a parent, or the introduction of new adults into the child’s home environment when those changes impact the child’s safety or emotional well‑being.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory requirement of a “material and substantial change in circumstances” for custody modification, but it does so to say that the changes identified (the mother’s relocation, work schedule, extended‑family contact, and temporary court‑ordered custody shift) did NOT constitute such a change. The court expressly rejects relying on the relocation and temporary custodial arrangement as a basis for modification and finds no post‑divorce changes sufficient to justify changing custody. It does not hold that changes in environment, parental conduct, or new adults in the home, even when affecting the child’s well‑being, qualify as material changes; rather, it concludes those types of facts in this case did not meet the standard.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements…”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A material and substantial change in circumstances can include changes in the child’s environment, the conduct or circumstances of a parent, or the introduction of new adults into the child’s home environment when those changes impact the child’s safety or emotional well‑being.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with initial custody determinations and emphasizes that all relevant factors must be weighed in terms of the child’s welfare, but it does not address the standard for modifying an existing custody order or define what constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances.” The case focuses on proper application of the best‑interests standard and the need for findings about the child’s current environment, not on when changed circumstances justify modification, nor on new adults in the home as a change‑in‑circumstances concept.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’ … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment … and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time, including requiring supervised parenting time or restricting the presence of third parties, in order to protect a child from potential harm.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time, including requiring supervised parenting time or restricting the presence of third parties, in order to protect a child from potential harm.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time, including requiring supervised parenting time or restricting the presence of third parties, in order to protect a child from potential harm.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child in custody determinations, and on compliance with statutory requirements for written findings when shared custody is ordered in the presence of a 209A order. It does not discuss, authorize, or illustrate the court’s equitable authority to impose specific conditions on parenting time such as supervised visitation or restrictions on third parties. No portion of the decision addresses conditional or supervised parenting time orders, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time, including requiring supervised parenting time or restricting the presence of third parties, in order to protect a child from potential harm.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation in terms of the children’s best interests and upholds a reduction in the father’s visitation time, but it does not address supervised parenting time, restrictions on third parties, or the scope of the court’s equitable authority to impose such specific conditions. The quoted language acknowledges that visitation may be limited to promote the child’s best interests, yet it stays at a general level and does not establish or analyze the particular forms of conditions described in the proposition. Therefore, it does not provide direct authority for the claimed proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order... ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 233.”

Care & Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App..raw_text: Care & Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 615, 617–18 (1999)
Care & Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that a child’s exposure to an adult with a history of violence, criminal behavior, or restraining orders can justify limitations or conditions on parenting time when necessary to protect the child’s physical or emotional well‑being.
Care & Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion does not address restrictions on parenting time based on a child’s exposure to adults with histories of violence, criminal behavior, or restraining orders. Instead, it concerns standards for findings of parental unfitness and the legal standard for limiting or terminating visitation, focusing on whether visits are harmful to the child. There is no discussion of third-party adults with violent or criminal histories as a basis for conditioning or limiting parenting time, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Care & Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “Before visitation rights may be terminated, the trial judge ‘must make specific findings demonstrating that parental visits will harm the child . . . .’ Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 392 Mass. 719, 726 (1984). The same standard of clear and convincing evidence controls the decision to terminate a parent’s visitation rights as it does the decisions concerning parental unfitness in both care and protection and adoption proceedings.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, the Court must consider the child’s safety and welfare, including exposure to violence, volatile conflict, and the character and stability of adults in the child’s environment.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on weighing competing adoptive placements under a best-interests standard, emphasizing stability, developmental needs, and the capacity and stability of prospective caregivers. It does not discuss safety concerns framed as exposure to violence or volatile conflict in the child’s environment in the best‑interests analysis itself (the brief mention of parental domestic violence appears only in background on parental unfitness, which is not at issue on appeal). Thus, while the case supports considering the character and stability of adults and the child’s developmental welfare, it does not clearly support the full proposition, particularly the “exposure to violence/volatile conflict” component, as a required best‑interests factor.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development… As the trier of fact, he was in the best position to evaluate all the evidence, contradictory at times.” (428 Mass. at 228–29).

Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.raw_text: Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 132, 141 (2004)
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, the Court must consider the child’s safety and welfare, including exposure to violence, volatile conflict, and the character and stability of adults in the child’s environment.
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames parental unfitness and custody determinations in terms of the child’s best interests, requiring consideration of the parent’s character, mental stability, home environment, and the child’s needs. It further holds that domestic violence and the child’s exposure to it are fundamental factors that must be expressly evaluated, with detailed findings on the effects of such violence on the child and the abusive parent’s fitness. This directly aligns with considering the child’s safety, exposure to violence and volatile conflict, and the character and stability of adults in the child’s environment.
Care & Protection of Lillith, 61 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt:
“Parental unfitness must be determined by taking into consideration a parent’s character, temperament, conduct, mental stability, home environment, and capacity to provide for the child in the same context with the child’s particular needs, affections and age.” …

“[T]he evidence of domestic violence in this case may be dated, and in part disputed, it was sufficient to require the express consideration of the issue as set forth in Custody of Vaughn… we remand the case for clarification of the judge’s findings on domestic violence, its effects on the child, and its relationship to the father’s ability to parent.”

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: Upon information and belief, the Defendant’s Partner has had a prior restraining order (abuse prevention order under G.L. c. 209A) issued against them by a previous intimate partner.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31, 31A.proposition: Reasonable conditions on parenting time, such as restrictions on the presence of third parties with violent histories or supervised visitation, are appropriate and within the Court’s discretion when necessary to protect a child’s best interests.
